scenario.description: Does creatine monohydrate supplementation increase lean body mass in adults performing resistance training?

parameters.intervention: Creatine monohydrate supplementation (3-5g/day maintenance or 20g/day loading phase followed by 3-5g/day maintenance)
parameters.outcome: Change in lean body mass (kg) measured by DEXA, BIA, or other validated methods

conclusion.claim: Creatine monohydrate supplementation combined with resistance training increases lean body mass in adults

outcome.effectSize: 0.7-1.5 kg additional lean body mass gain compared to placebo over 6-12 weeks
outcome.mechanismOfAction: Increases intramuscular creatine phosphate stores, enabling higher training volume and intensity, which stimulates muscle protein synthesis and hypertrophy
outcome.clinicalSignificance: Modest but consistent effect across populations. Individual response varies based on baseline muscle creatine levels (vegetarians show larger gains)
qualifications: Effect requires concurrent resistance training (creatine alone has minimal effect on lean body mass)
Individual response varies (some individuals are 'non-responders' with baseline high muscle creatine)
Effect size is moderate (~5-10% additional gain beyond training alone)
Safety profile excellent at recommended doses (3-5g/day) based on 25+ years of research

evidenceBasis.citation: Harris et al. (1992). Elevation of creatine in resting and exercised muscle of normal subjects by creatine supplementation. Clinical Science, 83(3), 367-374.
evidenceBasis.summary: Foundational study demonstrating creatine supplementation increases muscle creatine stores by 10-40%, with larger increases in individuals with initially low levels.

evidenceBasis.citation: Candow, D.G., et al. (2022). Influence of age, sex, and type of exercise on the efficacy of creatine supplementation on lean body mass: A systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized clinical trials. Nutrition, 100, 111659.
evidenceBasis.summary: Meta-analysis of 35 RCTs with 1,192 participants. Overall, creatine increased LBM by 0.68 kg (95% CI: 0.26-1.11). Effect larger with resistance training (1.1-1.5 kg) than other exercise types. High-quality evidence with GRADE assessment.

evidenceBasis.citation: Antonio, J., et al. (2021). Common questions and misconceptions about creatine supplementation: what does the scientific evidence really show? Journal of the International Society of Sports Nutrition, 18(1), 13.
evidenceBasis.summary: Comprehensive review of 500+ peer-reviewed publications. Confirms safety and efficacy of creatine monohydrate for increasing lean body mass when combined with resistance training. Addresses and refutes common misconceptions.

evidenceBasis.citation: Forbes, S.C., et al. (2023). The Effects of Creatine Supplementation Combined with Resistance Training on Regional Measures of Muscle Hypertrophy: A Systematic Review with Meta-Analysis. Nutrients, 15(9), 2116.
evidenceBasis.summary: Bayesian meta-analysis of 10 studies with direct imaging (MRI, CT, ultrasound). Pooled effect size 0.11 (95% CrI: -0.02 to 0.25), indicating small but favorable effect on regional muscle hypertrophy.

evidenceBasis.citation: Kreider, R.B., et al. (2017). International Society of Sports Nutrition position stand: safety and efficacy of creatine supplementation in exercise, sport, and medicine. Journal of the International Society of Sports Nutrition, 14(18).
evidenceBasis.summary: Position statement from leading scientific society. Extensive review of mechanism: creatine increases PCr stores, improves ATP resynthesis, enables more work during high-intensity exercise, leading to greater training adaptations.

prior.basis: Mechanism is biologically plausible (ATP-PCr system well-characterized). Base rate: approximately 50% of proposed sports nutrition supplements show statistically significant effects in well-designed RCTs. No strong prior expectation before empirical testing.
prior.source: General supplement efficacy base rate from systematic reviews of sports nutrition interventions

evidence.factor: Mechanistic studies confirm creatine increases muscle phosphocreatine stores by 10-40%
evidence.reasoning: Laboratory studies (Harris et al. 1992; Greenhaff et al. 1994) demonstrate creatine supplementation reliably increases intramuscular creatine and phosphocreatine. Mechanism confirmed in controlled settings with direct measurement via muscle biopsy. Moderate evidence that mechanism exists.

calculation.note: If creatine truly increases LBM via PCr mechanism, very likely (95%) we'd see PCr increases in muscle biopsy studies. If mechanism doesn't work, still 50% chance we'd see increases (placebo, measurement error). Moderate evidence.

empiricalData.source: Harris et al. (1992) muscle biopsy study, n=17 subjects
empiricalData.finding: Mean increase in total muscle creatine of 20% (range 10-40%)

evidence.factor: Early RCTs (1990s-2000s) show consistent lean body mass gains of 1-2 kg
evidence.reasoning: Multiple independent RCTs (Volek et al. 1999; Bemben et al. 2001; others) with 20-50 participants each show creatine + resistance training increases LBM by 1-2 kg more than placebo. Effect replicates across research groups. Moderate to strong evidence.

calculation.note: If creatine truly works, expect 85% of well-designed RCTs to show positive effect. If it doesn't work, expect 25% to show effect by chance (false positives). Seeing 10+ positive studies is moderate-strong evidence.

empiricalData.source: Collection of early RCTs reviewed in Kreider (2003) and Branch (2003)
empiricalData.finding: Approximately 12 out of 15 early RCTs showed significant LBM increases

evidence.factor: 2017 meta-analysis of 22 studies shows 1.37 kg additional lean body mass gain
evidence.reasoning: Large-scale synthesis (Devries & Phillips 2014 data analyzed by others) confirms effect persists across studies and populations. Statistical significance strong (p < 0.001). Effect size clinically meaningful. High-quality evidence emerges from aggregation of multiple trials.

calculation.note: If creatine works, expect meta-analysis of multiple RCTs to show consistent effect (95%). If it doesn't work, very unlikely (12%) that publication bias or other factors would create false positive in large meta-analysis. Strong evidence.

empiricalData.source: Meta-analysis referenced in systematic reviews circa 2017
empiricalData.finding: Weighted mean difference: 1.37 kg (95% CI: 0.97-1.76 kg)

evidence.factor: 2022 comprehensive meta-analysis (35 studies, 1,192 participants) confirms 0.68 kg overall gain, 1.1-1.5 kg with resistance training
evidence.reasoning: Most comprehensive synthesis to date (Candow et al. 2022). Effect size smaller than early studies (suggests early publication bias or selective reporting), but effect remains statistically significant and clinically meaningful. High credibility evidence. GRADE assessment rates evidence quality as HIGH.

calculation.note: Largest meta-analysis to date. If effect is real, expect 98% probability of detecting it with this sample size and methodology. If no true effect, only 8% probability of false positive this large. Strong evidence.

empiricalData.source: Candow et al. (2022) published in Nutrition
empiricalData.finding: Overall effect: 0.68 kg (95% CI: 0.26-1.11). Resistance training subgroup: 1.1-1.5 kg
empiricalData.dataAccessibility: Published open-access, full dataset available in supplementary materials

evidence.factor: Multiple Cochrane-quality systematic reviews from independent teams (ISSN, AIS, IOC) reach consistent conclusions across 25+ years of research
evidence.reasoning: Gold-standard systematic reviews from: (1) International Society of Sports Nutrition, (2) Australian Institute of Sport, (3) International Olympic Committee Sports Nutrition Consensus, (4) 500+ peer-reviewed papers spanning 1992-2024. Consensus is overwhelming. Effect replicates across research groups, countries, populations, time periods. Predictive validity confirmed: theoretical mechanism matches observed outcomes.

calculation.note: If creatine truly increases LBM, expect 99% probability that multiple independent systematic reviews over 25+ years would reach consistent positive conclusions. If no true effect, only 6% probability of this level of false consensus. Very strong evidence.

empiricalData.source: Multiple independent systematic reviews and position statements
reviews: Kreider et al. (2017) ISSN Position Stand
Antonio et al. (2021) ISSN Review (500+ papers)
Maughan et al. (2018) IOC Consensus Statement
Australian Institute of Sport Sports Supplement Framework (Group A: Strong Evidence)
empiricalData.supportingStudies: 475+ studies show positive or neutral results
empiricalData.contradictingStudies: ~25 studies show null results (often due to inadequate dosing, short duration, or lack of training stimulus)
empiricalData.dataAccessibility: All reviews published in open-access or widely-accessible journals

howToChangeMyMind: Large RCT (N>1,000) with adequate creatine dosing (5g/day), adequate duration (12+ weeks), proper resistance training protocol shows null effect → confidence drops to ~0.60

Discovery of systematic methodological flaw in muscle mass measurement: DEXA/BIA consistently overestimates lean body mass in creatine users due to increased water retention that doesn't reflect true muscle protein accretion → confidence drops to ~0.50
Meta-analysis controlling for publication bias shows entire effect disappears when unpublished studies included → confidence drops to ~0.40
Mechanism disproven: creatine shown NOT to increase muscle phosphocreatine stores in follow-up studies with better methodology → confidence drops to ~0.30
Long-term follow-up studies (5+ years) show initial LBM gains from creatine do not persist and are entirely water weight that dissipates → confidence drops to ~0.35

sources.keyFindings: Official position of ISSN. Comprehensive safety and efficacy review. Recommends creatine monohydrate at 3-5g/day.

sources.citation: Harris, R.C., Söderlund, K., & Hultman, E. (1992). Elevation of creatine in resting and exercised muscle of normal subjects by creatine supplementation. Clinical Science, 83(3), 367-374.
sources.keyFindings: Seminal paper demonstrating creatine supplementation increases muscle creatine stores by 10-40%. Foundation for all subsequent research.

metadata.funnelJustification: 25+ years of consistent research (1992-2025), 500+ peer-reviewed publications, multiple independent meta-analyses and systematic reviews from leading scientific organizations all converging on same conclusion. Mechanism understood and validated. Effect replicates across populations, geographies, research groups, and time periods. Meets criteria for 'canonical' knowledge: overwhelming consensus, extensive replication, predictive validity confirmed.

replicationStatus.note: Approximately 95% of studies show positive or neutral results. Null results typically attributable to inadequate dosing (<3g/day), insufficient duration (<4 weeks), lack of resistance training stimulus, or methodological limitations.
replicationStatus.independentReplications: Effect replicated by research groups in USA, Canada, Australia, Brazil, UK, Netherlands, and others across 25+ years

predictions.prediction: Creatine supplementation requires concurrent resistance training to increase LBM (creatine alone insufficient)
predictions.outcome: Confirmed: Candow et al. (2022) meta-analysis shows minimal effect without exercise, large effect with resistance training

predictions.prediction: Loading phase (20g/day for 5-7 days) increases muscle creatine faster than maintenance dose alone
predictions.outcome: Confirmed: Harris et al. (1992) and subsequent studies show loading achieves saturation in 5-7 days vs. 3-4 weeks for maintenance

predictions.prediction: Vegetarians and individuals with low baseline creatine show larger gains (they have more 'room to increase' stores)
predictions.outcome: Confirmed: Benton & Donohoe (2011) and others show vegetarians respond more than omnivores

predictions.prediction: Effect should be dose-dependent: higher doses (within safe limits) produce larger gains up to saturation point
predictions.outcome: Partially confirmed: 3-5g/day appears optimal; higher doses don't increase LBM gains once muscle stores saturated

predictiveAccuracy.note: Theoretical predictions from phosphocreatine mechanism have been consistently validated in empirical studies over 25+ years

safetyProfile.adverseEvents: No serious adverse events reported in 25+ years of research at recommended doses (3-5g/day)
commonMisconceptions: Kidney damage: Extensively studied, no evidence of harm in healthy individuals (Gualano et al. 2008; Antonio et al. 2021)
Dehydration/cramping: No evidence of increased risk (Lopez et al. 2009)
Hair loss: No evidence supporting this concern (Antonio et al. 2021)
safetyProfile.contraindications: Individuals with pre-existing kidney disease should consult physician. Generally recognized as safe (GRAS) for healthy adults.
safetyProfile.regulatoryStatus: Dietary supplement (not regulated as drug). Australian Institute of Sport: Group A (Strong Evidence, Safe, Effective)

relatedClaims.note: No credible scientific claims contradict this conclusion. Some poorly-designed studies show null results but these are explained by methodological limitations rather than contradicting the overall evidence base.

disclaimer.notMedicalAdvice: This knowledge claim is for informational purposes only and does not constitute medical advice. Consult a healthcare provider before beginning any supplementation regimen.
disclaimer.confidenceInterpretation: 0.90 confidence means we estimate a 90% probability this claim is correct based on current evidence. This is NOT certainty. Science is provisional and subject to revision with new evidence.
disclaimer.individualVariation: Individual results may vary. Approximately 20-30% of individuals are 'non-responders' who do not show significant creatine uptake into muscle, likely due to already-high baseline levels.
disclaimer.consultExpertReason: Confidence >0.85 with extensive safety data suggests professional consultation not mandatory for healthy adults, though always advisable before starting supplementation.
